header: Fashion moves fast for young girls. They try on new clothes and discard old identities. At this age they're open to new style suggestions but you can't be too forceful. With this in mind, we worked with Francesca's to re-imagine their brand as a helpful big sister to help their young customers navigate the early years of adolescence.

layout.title: Time for a change
text: When Francesca's came to us, their brand was stale. Their 11-15 year old female customers had grown more sophisticated than when the company was first founded in 2006. Girls now preferred hipper brands like Madewell and Asos.
But at the same time, the company didn't want to alienate the parents of these young women. We came up with a brand direction which tested very well with everyone. It was hipper, but not too hip.

layout.title: The Strategy
text: Since these young women were still figuring out their sense of style, we wanted to hold their hand a bit â€“ much like a big sister.

To deliver on this we came up with the idea of  an "editorial" browsing experience to subtly reveal style suggestions. The experience would be the online equivalent to flipping through a fashion magazine. Like how browsing Teen Vogue might reveal new fashion trends.

We put the editorial concept in front of users and it proved to be the most popular feature we tested. After getting validation, we designed a CMS that allowed the Francesca's editorial team to regularly update item pairings that worked well together.

In addition to the rebrand, we also made a concerted effort to optimize Francesca's checkout experience. We designed several checkout flows and did user testing to find which one worked best. The two winning designs were later A/B tested by the client to further optimize the site.
